article.description: Michael Bauer scored 13 points in the first half as the 17th-ranked Golden Gophers completed a perfect four-game homestand with a 79-52 rout of Bethune-Cookman.
article.headline: Rickert's absence causes no problem for Gophers
article.linkText: Even with Rickert sick, Gophers hammer Bethune-Cookman
article.story:
MINNEAPOLIS (AP) -- Rick Rickert was sick with the flu, so Minnesota (No. 17 EPSN/USA Today, No. 20 AP) tested its strength without its leading scorer.

Michael Bauer scored 13 of his 19 points in the first half for the Golden Gophers in a 79-52 victory Friday night over Bethune-Cookman.

"Rick Rickert is a great player -- we all know that,'' said Moe Hargrow, who finished with 15 points and eight rebounds. "But we had to see what we could do without him. Even though it was Bethune-Cookman, I think we made a statement.''

Jerry Holman had 15 points and nine rebounds for Minnesota (4-0), which plays its first road game at Nebraska on Sunday.

A turnaround jumper by Rickert with 9 seconds left -- as well as some tough defense -- pushed the Gophers past Georgia Tech 64-63 on Wednesday.

	   Minnesota had its on-the-ball defense working well again Friday.

Hargrow helped hold Wildcats leading scorer Richard Toussaint to 13 points on 5-for-21 shooting -- well below his 22.3 average.

But coach Dan Monson was frustrated by Minnesota's rebounding
performance. Minnesota had 45 rebounds to Bethune-Cookman's 39, but
the Wildcats had 18 of those on offense.

"The rebounding is my biggest concern going into Nebraska,''
Monson said. "We've just got to be able to squeeze balls better.
We're there. We just don't come up with the ball enough.''

Maurice Riddick added 10 points for Bethune-Cookman (1-3), which
had only two starters taller than 6-foot-3 and nobody over 6-8.

"This is one that scares a team,'' Bauer said. "When you have a smaller team in with nothing to lose, they can come in and do whatever they want.''

But the Wildcats weren't able to do that. They shot 4-for-17 from beyond the 3-point line.

"I just had a poor night shooting,'' Toussaint said. "Don't get me wrong, they play good defense. Just, nothing was falling for me.''

Against Georgia last Saturday, Minnesota overcame an 0-for-5 shooting performance by Rickert in the second half and beat the Bulldogs 72-69 on a buzzer-beating 3-pointer by Bauer.

Rickert's illness gave the Gophers another chance to run their
offense without the sophomore star forward.

Bauer got the start and injected some energy into an otherwise
bland first half. The crowd of 12,145 was noisier at halftime
during a girls' grade school game.

Bauer had eight points in a 14-0 Minnesota run early in the game
that put the Gophers up 16-4 with 13:34 left in the first half.

	   "We needed a win like this,'' Hargrow said.

Minnesota, which defeated Georgia and Georgia Tech by a total of
four points, received some contributions from subs Steve Esselink
(eight points in 13 minutes), Stan Gaines (six points). Jeff Hagen
saw some extended playing time.

The Gophers were also without reserve guard Aaron Robinson, suspended for at least two games by Monson for a team rules violation related to academics.

"Same old song,'' said Monson, who kicked guard Kris Collins off the team last month for failing to keep up with his classes. Robinson "is going to stay home (Sunday), and he's going to study.''

This is the fourth time Bethune-Cookman, from the Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference, has played at Minnesota. The Gophers have won each time.
